title: Specialist Music Schools
subtitle: How to cope with a child who shows outstanding musical ability?

cards.text: How to cope with a child who shows outstanding musical ability? It's not always clear how best to develop and encourage their gift. Many parents may even fail to recognise and respond to their child's need until frustration explodes into difficult or uncooperative behaviour.
cards.question: If a child's musical ability is not recognised
cards.highlight: frustration explodes into difficult or uncooperative behaviour

cards.text: And while most schools are equipped to deal with children who are especially able in academic subjects, the musically gifted require special understanding which may not always be available in an ordinary school especially one where music is regarded as a secondary activity.
cards.question: What problem may musically gifted children face in ordinary schools?
choices: Music is not seen as an important subject.
Parents and teachers do not work together.
cards.highlight: music is regarded as a secondary activity

cards.text: Children at specialist music schools spend between one third and one half of an average day on musical activities: individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting and theory.
cards.question: What makes specialist music schools different from other schools?
choices: The children have mostly one-to-one lessons.
More than half the day is spent on music.
A range of musical training is offered.
cards.highlight: a range of musical training is offered

cards.text: Almost all the directors of the specialist schools express doubts about the wisdom of admitting children as young as seven into such an intense and disciplined environment.
cards.question: What do most school directors see as a possible disadvantage for pupils?
choices: They may not be mature enough on arrival.
There may be a discipline problem.
cards.highlight: doubts about ... admitting children as young as seven

cards.text: There is little doubt that setting musically gifted children apart from an early age can cause stress. Early signs of musical ability may disappear in teenage years, while natural competitiveness and the pressure to succeed can lead to a crushing sense of failure. But all specialist schools do keep a close watch on the progress of individual pupils, and offer help and advice if needed.
cards.question: A specialist musical education might be stressful for children if
choices: the teachers expect too much of them.
they do not progress as expected.

cards.text: Many musically gifted young people are also highly intelligent, well able to deal with academic pressure, and feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met. For these reasons, it may be better to wait until the child is old enough to be able to make his or her own decisions before considering a specialist education.

cards.highlight: feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met

cards.text: Those who are equally gifted academically may do very well within a less specialised environment; for instance, at a school with a first class music department, or else by combining a normal school routine with musical training at one of the junior departments at the music colleges.
cards.question: What would be a good alternative to specialised music schools for gifted children?
choices: Having special classes at the weekend.
Arranging visits from a specialist music teacher.
Waiting until they are old enough to go to college.
cards.highlight: combining a normal school routine with musical training
